text.p: Machine tool giant Giddings & Lewis Inc. Thursday rejected a $747 million hostile takeover offer from Harnischfeger Industries Inc. and said it was in talks with others about a possible transaction.

Giddings said its board carefully considered the manufacturing equipment maker's offer of $19 a share and assumption of about $116 million in debt, which Harnischfeger announced April 25, and decided it was inadequate.
Giddings said financial adviser Credit Suisse First Boston Corp. found Harnischfeger's offer was financially inadequate for Giddings shareholders other than Harnischfeger.
Fond du Lac, Wis.-based Giddings also said it had had preliminary discussions with other parties about their interest in a possible transaction. It did not identify the parties.
Harnischfeger, based in the Milwaukee suburb of St. Francis, Wis., said Giddings' response confirmed its decision to take the offer directly to shareholders.
"Today's (Giddings) statement offers nothing to shareholders. Our bid offers real value and we will pursue it with dispatch," Harnischfeger Chief Executive Jeffery Grade said in a statement.
Analysts said even though Giddings was in talks with some parties, the company might not be able to find a taker willing to offer much more than Harnischfeger.

"I just think that list of potential bidders is limited," said William Cooke, an analyst who follows Giddings for McDonald & Co. Investments. "I'm not aware that any domestic machine tool makers would be interested in Giddings."
At the same time, a foreign firm seeking to buy Giddings could face scrutiny from the U.S. government because some of Giddings customers have defence contracts, analysts said.

Harnischfeger reiterated it plans to seek a special shareholder meeting where it would ask shareholders to remove Giddings' board. If the board is removed, Harnischfeger would then ask the new board to remove Giddings "poison pill" takeover defence.

Harnischfeger also has filed a lawsuit challenging the completeness and accuracy of filings Giddings made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The lawsuit could be used as a vehicle to ask the court to prevent Giddings from employing its takeover defence or taking other action to prevent a takeover, Harnischfeger said.
The $19-a-share offer was about a 39 percent premium over Giddings' closing price the day the offer was announced, and analysts still doubt Giddings will receive a much higher bid.
But Harnischfeger might raise its offer, possibly to as high as $21 a share, if it were convinced there were other serious offers for Giddings, analysts said.
"I still think the most likely scenario is Harnischfeger will buy this company," said J. Blair Brumely, an analyst who follows both companies for Dain Bosworth Inc.
Giddings stock rose 12.5 cents to $20.625 on Nasdaq. Harnischfeger fell $1.25 to $40.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Harnischfeger said when it made the offer it hoped to use Giddings to expand into the fragmented industrial products service business.
Giddings' products include drill point grinders, lathes, cutting tools and industrial computers.
Harnischfeger makes heavy machinery and manufacturing systems for papermaking, mining and materials handling.
